definition: A switch type that moves straight down without any bump or click. Known for smooth keypresses, making them popular for gaming and fast typing.
A switch with a noticeable bump partway through the keypress that lets you feel when the key registers. Popular for typing because the bump provides feedback without being noisy.
A switch that produces an audible click sound along with a tactile bump when pressed. Satisfying to type on but not recommended for shared or quiet spaces.
A switch with built-in rubber dampeners that reduce noise on the downstroke and upstroke. Ideal for office use and shared spaces where noise is a concern.

A switch that uses magnets and sensors instead of physical metal contacts to register keypresses. Allows adjustable actuation points and has virtually unlimited lifespan since there are no parts that physically touch to wear out.

The cross-shaped (+) part of a switch that moves up and down and connects to the keycap. The stem's shape determines whether a switch is linear, tactile, or clicky, and its material affects smoothness and sound.
The outer shell of a switch, made up of a top and bottom piece, that holds the stem and spring. Housing material (nylon, polycarbonate, etc.) significantly affects the switch's sound and feel.
The metal coil inside a switch that provides resistance and pushes the stem back up after a keypress. Spring weight (measured in grams) determines how heavy the keypress feels.
A thin metal piece inside the switch that makes contact with the stem to register a keypress. The leaf is what actually sends the electrical signal to your computer when you press a key.
The exact point during a keypress where the switch's leaf and stem connect to register the keystroke. This is where the electrical circuit completes and the key input is sent to your computer.

The amount of force (measured in grams) needed to press a key far enough to register a keystroke. Lower values (35-45g) feel light and effortless, while higher values (60g+) feel heavier and more deliberate.

The total force needed to press a key all the way down to the bottom. This is always higher than the actuation force since the spring compresses more. Heavy typists who bottom out keys should pay attention to this spec.

The total distance a key moves from the top of the keystroke to the very bottom, usually measured in millimeters. Standard MX switches have about 4mm of travel. Shorter travel means faster keypresses.
The distance a key moves from the resting position to the actuation point where the keystroke registers. Shorter pre-travel means faster input registration, which is popular for gaming.

A switch stem with an extended pole on the bottom that hits the housing earlier, shortening total travel and creating a sharper, more defined bottom-out feel and sound. Popular for clacky sound profiles.
Switches that come pre-lubed from the manufacturer. Quality varies widely between brands. Factory lube saves time but is rarely as consistent as hand-lubing, which many enthusiasts prefer.

Replacing the spring inside a switch with one of a different weight or type to change how heavy or light the keypress feels. A common and easy modification that can dramatically alter the typing experience.
Replacing the stem of one switch with a stem from a different switch to combine characteristics from both. This is how famous combinations like the Holy Panda were originally created.
A switch or keycap that uses the standard Cherry MX cross-shaped (+) stem design. Almost all modern mechanical keyboard switches and keycaps follow this standard, making them interchangeable.
Thin sheets of material placed between the top and bottom housing of a switch to reduce wobble and change the sound. Films tighten up loose housings, making the switch feel and sound more consistent.

A deep, low-pitched sound that many keyboard enthusiasts consider the most desirable sound profile. Often described as a satisfying 'thock' on each keypress. Achieved through nylon housings, foam mods, and certain plate materials.
A higher-pitched, sharper sound on each keypress. Often produced by polycarbonate housings, long pole stems, and aluminum or brass plates. Some people prefer clack over thock for its crispness.
A smooth, warm sound profile with a slightly muffled quality. Popularized by NovelKeys Cream switches. Often associated with POM housings and nylon materials that produce a pleasing, rounded sound.
A lively, bouncy sound with a quick, snappy quality on each keypress. Poppy keyboards feel responsive and energetic. Polycarbonate plates and housings often contribute to this sound.
A very quiet, dampened sound profile with minimal noise on each keypress. Achieved through foam modifications, silent switches, and dampening materials. Ideal for office or shared environments.
A clean, sharp sound that is well-defined on each keypress without excess resonance or rattle. Often associated with well-tuned stabilizers and metal plates.
An unwanted metallic ringing sound produced by the spring inside a switch, especially noticeable after releasing a key. Can be reduced by lubing the spring or using switches with extended springs.
An undesirable rough or gritty feeling and sound when pressing a switch, caused by friction between the stem and housing. Stock Cherry MX switches are often described as scratchy. Fixed by lubing.
The overall sound character of a keyboard, determined by the combination of switches, plate material, case material, and modifications. Common profiles include thocky, clacky, creamy, and poppy.
A recording or video demonstrating how a keyboard sounds while typing. Sound tests help buyers understand a keyboard's sound profile before purchasing. Found commonly on YouTube and Reddit.
A low-profile keycap shape that is slightly sculpted for each row. The most popular keycap profile in the hobby, offering a comfortable balance between low height and ergonomic sculpting.

A tall, spherical-top keycap profile with aggressive sculpting between rows. SA keycaps produce a deeper sound due to their height and are loved for their retro aesthetic, though some find them too tall.
A uniform (non-sculpted) spherical-top keycap profile where every row is the same height. This makes keycaps interchangeable between rows, which is useful for non-standard layouts.

A tall, deeply sculpted keycap profile designed by Matt3o, inspired by vintage terminal keyboards. Has a scooped top and dramatic row-to-row height changes. Typing on MT3 feels very deliberate and satisfying.

A uniform (non-sculpted) keycap profile with a flat top surface, slightly taller than DSA. Every key is the same shape, making them versatile for alternative layouts. A popular budget-friendly profile.

The most common keycap profile found on prebuilt keyboards. Slightly taller and less sculpted than Cherry profile. If you have used a regular mechanical keyboard, you have likely typed on OEM keycaps.

A keycap printing method where dye is heat-pressed into the plastic, becoming part of the material itself. Dye-sub legends never wear off or fade. Limited to printing darker colors on lighter keycaps.

A premium keycap manufacturing method using two layers of plastic molded together to form the legends. The legends can never fade or wear away since they are a separate piece of plastic. Allows any color combination.

Polybutylene terephthalate, a type of plastic used for keycaps. PBT keycaps are more durable, resistant to shine (oil buildup), and produce a slightly deeper sound compared to ABS. Most enthusiasts prefer PBT.

Acrylonitrile butadiene styrene, a common keycap plastic. ABS is smoother, allows more vibrant colors, and is used for most doubleshot keycaps. The downside is that ABS develops a shiny, greasy look over time from finger oils.

The letters, numbers, and symbols printed or molded onto keycaps. Legend quality and durability depend on the production method. Doubleshot and dye-sub legends last the longest, while pad-printed legends wear off quickly.
A complete set of keycaps designed to cover an entire keyboard, often with extra keys for different layouts. Sets come in various profiles, materials, and colorways. High-end sets can cost $100-200+.

A keyboard case machined from aluminum, providing excellent build quality, weight, and a premium feel. Aluminum produces a crisp, slightly higher-pitched sound profile. Most mid-to-high-end custom keyboards use aluminum cases.

A keyboard case made from clear or translucent polycarbonate plastic. PC cases produce a deeper, softer sound compared to aluminum and allow RGB lighting to shine through. Popular for see-through builds.

A keyboard case made from layered sheets of acrylic, often frosted or clear. Acrylic cases diffuse RGB lighting beautifully and produce a hollow, somewhat resonant sound. Common in budget and DIY keyboard kits.
A keyboard plate made from aluminum that sits between the switches and PCB, holding the switches in place. Aluminum plates provide a firm, stiff typing feel with a crisp, bright sound signature.

A keyboard plate made from polycarbonate that offers more flex than aluminum or brass plates. PC plates produce a deeper, softer sound and a bouncier typing feel, making them popular for gasket mount builds.

A keyboard plate made from the same fiberglass material used in PCBs. FR4 plates are lightweight, affordable, and offer moderate flex. They produce a balanced sound between the stiffness of aluminum and softness of PC.
A heavy, dense keyboard plate made from brass that provides a very stiff typing feel with a unique bright, pingy sound. Brass plates add significant weight and have a premium, luxurious feel.
Slots or cuts made in a keyboard plate to allow it to bend more during typing. Flex cuts reduce stiffness and create a softer, bouncier typing feel, especially popular with gasket mount boards.

A mounting style where the plate is suspended between strips of soft gasket material (usually silicone or rubber) sandwiched between the plate and case. This isolates the typing surface for a softer, bouncier feel and reduced case ping.

A mounting style where the plate screws directly to the top part of the case. Provides a firm, consistent typing feel with good sound. Less flex than gasket mount but more than tray mount. A proven, reliable design.

The most common and affordable mounting style where the PCB screws into standoffs on the bottom case. Simple and effective but can create uneven flex, with areas near screw points feeling stiffer than others.
A mounting style where the plate is sandwiched between the top and bottom case halves. The plate sits on the bottom case edge and the top case holds it down. Provides a uniform feel across the board.
A mounting style that uses rubber O-rings to cushion and isolate the plate from the case. Similar concept to gasket mount but uses ring-shaped dampeners. Creates a soft, bouncy typing experience.
A design where the plate is built directly into the top case as one piece, rather than being a separate component. Common in budget keyboards. Provides a very stiff, rigid typing feel with no flex.

Refers to switches or stabilizers that clip directly onto the plate rather than the PCB. Plate-mount stabilizers are easier to install but cannot be swapped without removing all nearby switches first.

Refers to switches or stabilizers that attach directly to the PCB. PCB-mount (5-pin) switches have two extra plastic legs for stability. PCB-mount (screw-in) stabilizers are preferred by enthusiasts for their stability.

Applying lubricant (usually Krytox 205g0 for linears or Tribosys 3203 for tactiles) to switch components to reduce friction and noise. Hand-lubing switches is the single most impactful mod for improving smoothness and sound.

Applying layers of painter's tape to the back of the PCB to change the sound profile. The tape reflects sound waves differently, often resulting in a deeper, more muted sound. A simple, free, and reversible mod.

Placing a thin sheet of PE (polyethylene) foam between the PCB and switches. This changes how sound resonates through the board, often creating a poppy, marble-like sound. Very popular and easy to do.

Another name for the tape mod, named after the community member who popularized it. Involves applying masking or painter's tape to the back of the PCB. Often combined with other foam mods for best results.
Placing small strips of fabric bandage material on the PCB under the stabilizer housings to cushion the impact and reduce rattle. An early and simple mod for quieter, better-sounding stabilizers.

Wrapping the stabilizer wire with a thin strip of bandage or fabric to eliminate wire rattle and ticking. Named after the community member who popularized it. One of the most effective stabilizer tuning techniques.

Cutting or removing parts of the plate between certain switch positions to allow sections of the plate to flex independently. Creates a softer, more flexible typing feel in specific areas of the keyboard.
Placing small rubber O-rings on keycap stems to shorten key travel and reduce the sound of bottoming out. A cheap, easy mod for quieter typing. Some dislike the mushy feeling it creates.

The process of lubing, clipping, and modifying stabilizers to eliminate rattle and create a consistent, smooth feel on larger keys like spacebar, shift, and enter. Well-tuned stabs make a huge difference in sound quality.

Various foam materials (IXPE, Poron, EVA, silicone) placed inside the keyboard case, between the PCB and plate, or under the PCB. Foam reduces hollowness, dampens ping, and helps shape the overall sound profile.

A keyboard PCB with sockets that allow switches to be inserted and removed without soldering. Hot-swap makes it easy to try different switches and is strongly recommended for beginners. Most modern kits offer hot-swap.

A keyboard where switches are permanently attached to the PCB using solder. Soldered builds provide a more secure connection and slightly different sound characteristics, but changing switches requires desoldering.

LED lights positioned on the south (bottom) side of each switch on the PCB. Preferred by enthusiasts because they avoid interference with Cherry-profile keycaps. Most modern custom PCBs use south-facing LEDs.

LED lights positioned on the north (top) side of each switch. Shine through keycap legends better but can cause interference with Cherry-profile keycaps on certain switches, resulting in a 'clack' on the upstroke.

Printed Circuit Board - the main electronic board inside a keyboard that registers keypresses and sends signals to your computer. The PCB determines features like hot-swap support, LED placement, and programmability.

A community-organized pre-order where a product is manufactured only after enough orders are collected. Common for keycap sets and high-end keyboards. Delivery often takes 6-18 months. Products are usually cheaper than aftermarket.
A product that is currently available to buy and ship immediately, without waiting for a group buy. Many enthusiasts prefer in-stock items to avoid long wait times, even if they cost slightly more.

A survey or post (often abbreviated IC) where a designer gauges community interest before running a group buy. ICs let you vote on colorways, provide feedback on designs, and get notified when the group buy launches.

Refers to the production round of a group buy product. R1 means first round (initial run), R2 means second round (re-run due to demand). Later rounds may include improvements or new colorways based on community feedback.

Mechanisms that support wider keys (spacebar, shift, enter, backspace) to keep them level and prevent wobble. Poorly tuned stabilizers cause rattling sounds. Screw-in (PCB-mount) stabilizers are preferred over clip-in for stability.

A compact keyboard layout with only the main alphanumeric keys, removing the function row, navigation cluster, and numpad. About 61 keys total. Functions are accessed through key layers. Popular for its minimalist look and desk space savings.

A keyboard layout that adds arrow keys and a few navigation keys to a 60% layout, without a function row. About 66-68 keys. Considered the sweet spot between compactness and functionality by many enthusiasts.

A keyboard layout that includes the function row (F1-F12) and arrow keys in a compact arrangement. About 82-84 keys. The most popular custom keyboard size because it keeps essential keys without taking up too much desk space.

Tenkeyless - a keyboard layout that removes only the number pad from a full-size keyboard, keeping the function row and navigation cluster. About 87 keys. Great for users who want familiar layout with more desk space for mouse movement.

A keyboard with all standard keys including the number pad, function row, and navigation cluster. About 104 keys. Preferred by users who frequently use the numpad for data entry, accounting, or number-heavy work.

A compact layout that fits all the keys of a full-size keyboard (including numpad) into a smaller footprint by eliminating gaps between key clusters. About 99-100 keys. Great for numpad users who want a smaller board.

An open-source keyboard firmware that allows deep customization of key mappings, macros, layers, and lighting. QMK is the most powerful firmware option but requires some technical knowledge to configure. Flashed via command line or QMK Toolbox.

A user-friendly graphical tool for customizing keyboards that run QMK firmware. VIA lets you remap keys, create macros, and adjust lighting in real time through a simple web or desktop app. No coding required.

Polyoxymethylene (also called Delrin or acetal), a self-lubricating plastic used in switch stems and housings. POM's natural lubricity means switches using it tend to be smoother and require less lube. Produces a deep, thocky sound.

A common material used for switch housings and keyboard cases. Nylon housings produce a deeper, warmer sound compared to polycarbonate. Many enthusiasts prefer nylon-housed switches for thocky sound profiles.

A transparent thermoplastic used for switch housings, keyboard cases, and plates. PC housings produce a higher-pitched, clackier sound than nylon. PC cases allow RGB light diffusion and have a unique acoustic character.

Ultra-high-molecular-weight polyethylene, an extremely smooth and self-lubricating plastic used in premium switch stems and housings. UHMWPE components require minimal lubing and provide exceptional smoothness.

The smallest common keyboard layout, removing the number row entirely along with function and navigation keys. About 40-48 keys. Everything is accessed through multiple layers. Requires significant adjustment but offers maximum desk space.

A compact full-size layout that includes a numpad but reduces spacing between key clusters. Similar to 96% but with a small gap between the main keys and numpad. Found in some vintage keyboards and modern customs.

The most popular switch lubricant in the keyboard hobby, a thick PFPE grease ideal for linear switches. Applied to switch stems, housing rails, and springs for dramatically improved smoothness and sound. Too thick for tactile switches.

A thinner lubricant popular for tactile switches because it improves smoothness without reducing the tactile bump. Less viscous than Krytox 205g0, making it harder to over-apply. Good for beginners who want a safer lube option.
